oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cumberland Gap: town hall
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of a two-story brick building on a small hill; six rectangular windows and double glass doors on front facade; three windows and air conditioning unit on left facade; brick chimney and gable shingle roof; stone stairs in hill leading up to front door; car parked on left side of building; sign over door reads "City Hall"

For over two hundred years, Cumberland Gap has served as a significant passageway to the lands west of the Appalachian mountains. The Cumberland Gap Historic District is significant as evidence to the patterns of Claiborne County's history as a late nineteenth and early twentieth century mining town funded by foreign capitalists as well as its associations with Wilderness Road. American Association, Limited had its headquarters in Cumberland Gap.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Historic districts; Historic buildings; Cumberland Gap (Tenn.)
